screen.welcome_message: The Safe Delivery App is an aid for the skilled birth attendant to manage the complications occurring during pregnancy, childbirth and the first weeks after birth.

chapters.content:
Introduction & Aim

The Safe Delivery App is an aid for the skilled birth
attendant to manage the complications to women and babies during pregnancy, childbirth and the first weeks after birth. Life threatening complications can happen to any pregnant women and her child, they often occur unexpected in “low risk pregnancies”.

Each year almost three million babies are born dead and as many die within the first month of life, while over a quarter of a million women die due to pregnancy and child birth totalling more than the number of deaths caused by the ‘three big diseases’ HIV/AIDS, tuberculosis and malaria.

Assuring the quality of basic emergency obstetric and neonatal care (BEmONC) has proven to be of key importance to reduce death and disability of mothers and newborn.

Videos

The United Nations established 7 “signal functions” of BEmONC that every skilled birth attendant must be able to perform. These signal functions are all covered by the Safe Delivery App that has instruction videos on how to:

  1. Stop a post partum haemorrhage (PPH)
  2. Remove a retained placenta
  3. Manage maternal sepsis
  4. Manage hypertensive disorders
  5. Manage prolonged labour including how to perform vacuum extraction
  6. Perform manual vacuum aspiration at complications to abortion
  7. Resuscitate a newborn

Furthermore the Safe Delivery App has 2 videos on prevention of respectively;

  • Active Management of the Third Stage of Labour (AMTSL)
  • Management of newborn complications
  • Infection prevention

These instruction videos last around seven minutes. They are thought to be used as a self-teaching aid. They can be seen in full length or specific episodes can be chosen.

Action Cards

When you are in an emergency situation you may not have time to review the videos. Instead we have made “Action Cards” that have the essential recommendations for the management of the 7 BEmONC signal functions and early neonatal management.

Essential Drugs

The drug list contains useful information on the different drugs you should have available to perform BEmONC. The drugs are listed alphabetically with indications for use, dosage, when the drugs should not be used (contraindications) and common and rare adverse reactions to the drug.

Go through it to see if you have everything listed and make a purchase list of what you don’t have yet.

Procedures

Selected procedures are described in detail, for example how to insert a nasogastric tube and how to clean a manual vacuum aspirator.

Push Messages

Once in a while you will receive messages guiding you to interesting parts of the Safe Delivery App for you to explore.

Push!

Recent Updates!

We recently (as of April 2017) made some changes to the Safe Delivery App we think may interest you:

1. We updated the content based on the World Health Organization (WHO)’s new clinical guidelines.

2. We now structure our content according the clinical situation, for example Post Partum Haemorrhage, rather than by feature such as by video, allowing for more intuitive navigation in particular in emergency situations.

3. We added in drug lists that are specific to each clinical situation, in addition to the existing comprehensive drug list.

Learning Platform

Soon the Safe Delivery App will include a new Learning Platform.

Here you will be able to test and strengthen your knowledge of BEmONC and the additional three related topics covered in the Safe Delivery App through quizzes.

You will be able to track your personal learning journey and gain your personal certification as a Safe Delivery Champion.

Each theme has 3 levels and each of these levels consist of 12 questions, which must be answered correctly in order to proceed to the next level.

There are three types of questions which may be answered in three different formats:
1) by choosing 1 correct answer when you see the symbol ◯
2) by choosing more correct answers when you see the symbol ☐ and
3) by arranging cards in the right order.

As a user you can create a profile and you have the possibility to create more than one user profile on the device.

A user profile can be created both online and offline on the device.

When creating an online user you will have the possibility to recover you password and thereby your progress on the learning platform if you change your phone or have to re-install the Safe Delivery App.

Be aware that deleting the app from your phone will cause your progress to be lost – unless you log out of the platform before doing so.

The Safe Delivery Champion Certificate:

The certification test will be available to you 14 days after you have passed all themes in the Safe Delivery App Learning Platform with 3 stars in each level.

The certification test is a comprehensive test of knowledge of performing the clinical procedures described in the Safe Delivery App. The certification test consists of 15 cases with 1-7 questions for each – a total of 53 questions.

Once you have completed and passed the test you will receive a certificate with your new status as a Safe Delivery Champion.

The certificate will last for a year, and you can receive a print-out version of the certificate by email.

Thank you very much for downloading the Safe Delivery App.

We are full of admiration for your work and the lives you safe!

The Safe Delivery App was developed by:

The Hindi Safe Delivery App has been aligned to the Government of India's guidelines of basic emergency obstetric and neonatal care, and approved by the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare.

The content of this App has been translated, locally adapted and aligned to Government of India’s guidelines with support from Jhpiego.

The App was designed and produced by:

Financial Partners

The Safe Delivery App was funded by:

Thank you to all supporters who donated to our crowdfunding campaign for the Safe Delivery App at Indiegogo, November 2014.

The Safe Delivery App was developed and validated with contributions from a group of international experts and doctors within obstetrics and paediatrics. We are very thankful for this support, which ensures a high level of validated content.

For more information on contributions to the development of the App go to our webpage:

www.maternity.dk

All rights to the content of this application belong to the developers and/or University of Copenhagen, University of Southern Denmark and Maternity Foundation.

All pictures, graphics, drawings and illustrations belong to the developers and/or University of Copenhagen, University of Southern Denmark and Maternity Foundation unless otherwise stated with the exception of code written by others and used in/for the application.

The content or any part hereof must not be copied in any form, nor electronic unless specific permission is granted from the developers.

However use for personal –non-commercial purposes is accepted on the following conditions:

  1. The documents/guidelines remains un-edited and without any changes
  2. That no fee is charged for private use
  3. That copyrights and the names of the developers and/or University of Copenhagen, University of Southern Denmark and Maternity Foundation are explicitly referred to as source of information.

Terms of use

Please read and accept the terms of use before using the application

This application is to be used as a guide and learning aid only.

The instructions herein represent general and accepted principles for assistance and actions in childbirth and the first month of life only.

Each given situation requires an individual judgement and approach, and this application should be used together with national guidelines and local working agreements.

The use of this application and its content is at your own risk, and the developer of this application and its content expressly disclaims any liability for any injury and/or damage to persons and/or property arising from the use of this application.

Any usage of the application will be tracked to enable us to monitor usage, behaviour and progress.

All data will be kept anonymous.

Maternity Foundation will share data in an anonymised and aggregated form and for the sole purpose of creating a better application for our users and more efficient programmes around it.

This means that your personal learning journey will not be known to anyone but yourself and Maternity Foundation, unless you choose to share it.

Maternity Foundation has updated its Privacy Policy and Terms of use, effective from, May 25, 2018. These changes were made primarily in preparation for the EU’s new data privacy law, the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR).

With these updates, Maternity Foundation reaffirms its commitment to safeguarding the personal data such as email adresses.

For more infomation go to the following link: https://www.maternity.dk/wp-content/uploads/2018/05/Privatlivs-og-cookiepolitik-til-hjemmeside.pdf.

Welcome

The Safe Delivery App is an aid for the skilled birth attendant and health worker, to manage complications occuring during pregnancy, childbirth and the first weeks after birth.

User profile questions

Before you access the content of this app we kindly ask you to take a few minutes to complete the following two questionnaires.Hereby you can follow your progress and we can monitor the effect of The Safe Delivery App and improve content where needed. All data will be kept anonymous

Thank You!

You now have access to the content of The Safe Delivery App.

We hope you will find it useful.

My learning

”My learning” is currently available on the Global English version.

Download the English version of the Safe Delivery App in order to enter the Global Learning Platform where you will be able to follow your personal learning progress.

Welcome! "My Learning" will help you learn the key elements of the 10 themes in the Safe Delivery App on Basic Emergency Obstetric and Neonatal Care.

As a learner, you can choose either to create an offline or online profile to track your progress. (The advantage to creating an online profile is that you can recover your learning progress via your password if you use another phone or tablet, or if the Safe Delivery App is re-installed.)

Each theme on "My Learning" has 3 levels with 12 questions. These questions must be answered correctly to proceed to the next level.

Two weeks after you have passed all 3 levels in all 10 themes, you can take the final Safe Delivery certificate exam and become a Safe Delivery Champion! If you provide us with an email address, we will send you a certification verifying your accomplishment.

Good luck with "My learning!"

chapters.content:
Using alcohol-based handrub is indicated when hands are visibly clean.

Use alcohol-based handrub before and after every procedure, such as before and after touching a patient, after touching patient's surroundings, before a clean procedure, after body fluid exposure risk and before and after wearing gloves.

Guide to Local Production:

WHO-recommended handrub formulations.

Liquids Required

  • Ethanol 96% OR Isopropyl alcohol 99.8%
  • Hydrogen peroxide 3%
  • Glycerol 98%
  • Sterile distilled OR boiled cold water

Materials Required

  • 10-litre glass or plastic bottles with screw-threaded stoppers, OR
  • 50-litre plastic tanks (preferably in polypropylene or high density polyethylene, translucent so as to see the liquid level), OR
  • Stainless steel tanks with a capacity of 80-100 litres (for mixing without overflowing)
  • Wooden, plastic or metal paddles for mixing
  • Measuring cylinders and measuring jugs
  • Plastic or metal funnel
  • 100 ml plastic bottles with leak-proof tops, OR
  • 500 ml glass or plastic bottles with screwtops.
    An alcoholmeter: the temperature scale is at the bottom and the ethanol concentration (percentage v/v) at the top.

Note:

    Glycerol: used as humectant, but other emollients may be used for skin care, provided that they are cheap, widely available and miscible in the water and alcohol and do not add to toxicity, or promote allergy.
    Hydrogen peroxide: used to inactivate contaminating bacterial spores in the solution and is not an active substance for hand antisepsis.
    Any further additive should be clearly labelled and be non-toxic in case of accidental ingestion.
    A colourant may be added to allow differentiation from other fluids, but should not add to toxicity, promote allergy, or interfere with antimicrobial properties. The addition of perfumes or dyes is not recommended due to risk of allergic reactions

10-litre preparations:

These can be prepared in 10-litre glass or plastic bottles with screw-treaded stoppers.

Recommended amounts of products:

10-litre preparations

Formulation 1

  • Ethanol 96%: 8333 ml
  • Hydrogen peroxide 3%: 417 ml
  • Glycerol 98%: 145 ml
  • Sterile distilled or boiled cold water: 1105 ml

Formulation 2

  • Isopropyl alcohol 99.8%: 7515 ml
  • Hydrogen peroxide 3%: 417 ml
  • Glycerol 98%: 145 ml
  • Sterile distilled or boiled cold water: 1923 ml

Final products:

Formulation 1

Final concentrations:

  • Ethanol 80% (v/v)
  • Glucerol 1.45% (v/v)
  • Hydrogen peroxide 0.125% (v/v)

Formulation 2

Final concentrations:

  • Isopropyl alcohol 75% (v/v)
  • Glycerol 1.45% (v/v)
  • Hydrogen peroxide 0.125% (v/v)

Step by Step Preparation:

1. The alcohol (Ethanol or Isopropyl) for the formula to be used is poured into the large bottle or tank up to the graduated mark.

2. Hydrogen peroxide is added using the measuring cylinder

3. Glycerol is added using a measuring cylinder.

As glycerol is very viscous and sticks to the wall of the measuring cylinder, it should be rinsed with some sterile distilled or cold boiled water and then emptied into the bottle/tank.

4. The bottle/tank is then topped up to the 10-litre mark with sterile distilled or cold boiled water

5. The lid or the screw cap is placed on the tank/bottle as soon as possible after preparation, in order to prevent evaporation.

6. The solution is mixed by shaking gently where appropriate or by using a paddle.

7. Immediately divide up the solution into its final containers (e.g. 500 or 100 ml plastic bottles), and place the bottles in quarantine for 72 hours before use.

This allows time for any spores present in the alcohol or the new/re-used bottles to be destroyed.

1. Pre-production analysis should be made every time an analysis certificate is not available to guarantee the titration of alcohol (i.e. local production).

Verify the alcohol concentration with the alcoholmeter and make the necessary adjustments in volume in the preparation formulation to obtain the final recommended concentration.

2. Post-production analysis is mandatory if either ethanol or an isopropanol solution is used.

Use the alcoholmeter to control the alcohol concentration of the final use solution.

The accepted limits should be fixed to ± 5% of the target concentration (75%–85% for ethanol).

3. The alcoholmeter shown in the image above is for use with ethanol; if used to control an isopropanol solution, a 75% solution will show 77% (± 1%) on the scale at 25°C.

Labelling should be in accordance with national guidelines and should include the following:

  • Name of institution, date of production and batch number.
  • WHO-recommended hand rub formulation.
  • For external use only.
  • Avoid contact with eyes.
  • Keep out of reach of children.
  • Date of production and batch number.
  • Use: Apply a palmful of alcohol-based handrub and cover all surfaces of the hands. Rub hands for 20- 30 seconds.
  • Composition: Ethanol or isopropanol, glycerol and hydrogen peroxide.
  • Flammable: Keep away from flame and heat.

• Production and storage facilities should ideally be air conditioned or cool rooms. No naked flames or smoking should be permitted in these areas.
  • WHO-recommended handrub formulations should not be produced in quantities exceeding 50- litres locally or in central pharmacies lacking specialised air conditioning and ventilation.
  • Since undiluted ethanol is highly flammable and may ignite at temperatures as low as 10°C, production facilities should directly dilute it to the above mentioned concentration.
  • The flashpoints of ethanol 80% (v/v) and of isopropyl alcohol 75% (v/v) are 17.5°C and 19°C, respectively.
  • National safety guidelines and local legal requirements must be adhered to the storage of ingredients and the final product.

Using 0.5% Chlorine Solution is indicated when instruments can be decontaminated and when to mix a disinfection solution used for cleaning high-risk areas.

Disinfection solution is made with detergent and 0.5% Chlorine Solution.

Chlorine in liquid bleach comes in different concentrations.

Any concentration can be used to make a dilute chlorine solution by applying the following formula:

% Chlorine in liquid bleach
Chlorine desired (0.5%)
-1
=
Total parts of water for each part of bleach

Example: To make a 0.5% chlorine solution from 5% bleach:

5%
0.5%
-1
=
9 parts of water for each part of bleach

Therefore, you must add 1 part of 5% bleach to 9 parts water to make a 0.5% chlorine solution.

Parts can be used for any unit of measure (e.g. litre or gallon) or any container used for measuring, such as a pitcher.

In countries where French products are available, the amount of active chlorine is usually expressed in degrees chlorum.

One degree chlorum is equivalent to 0.3% active chlorine.

Manual vacuum aspiration, or MVA, is a technique for uterine evacuation whose low cost, simplicity and portability make it an especially valuable reproductive-health technology.

MVA is used for evacuation of the uterus at incomplete first trimester abortions up to a gestational age of 12 weeks.

Especially at septic abortion and strong bleeding in relation to abortion the procedure is a life saving emergency procedure that must be performed with no delay.

Antibiotics should not delay the procedure.

Ideally antibiotics are given at the start of the procedure, though the procedure can be performed without antibiotics.

Cleaning After Use

Step 1:

Soak instruments immediately after use

Following the procedure, decontaminate and clean all aspirators that will be reused, by first putting unlock and open jointed instruments in a 0.5 % chlorine solution for maximum 10 min.

Hereafter clean the aspirators with a brush in a soap solution. Be aware the soap solution is made of detergent and water, not hand soap.

Rinse items with clean running water to remove all detergent.

Step 2:

Clean all aspirators thoroughly in warm water and detergent, not soap.

Wear gloves and face protection.

Disassemble the aspirator by pulling the cylinder out of the valve.

Remove the cap by pressing down the cap-release tabs with one hand and pulling off the cap with the other hand.

Open the hinged valve by pulling open the clasp.

Place right thumb alongside the right valve button and left thumb on the valve latch.

With the left thumb, pull up and to the left on the valve latch while pushing down and out on the valve body with the right thumb.

Remove the valve liner.

Disengage the collar stop by sliding it sideways under the retaining clip, or remove the collar stop completely.

Pull the plunger completely out.

Displace the plunger O-ring by squeezing its sides and rolling it into the groove below.

Emptying the bladder with a urine catheter is indicated:

  1. If a woman in labour fails to urinate spontaneously and the progress of labour is dissatisfactory, OR
  2. In cases of post partum haemorrhage, AND
  3. In any severely ill patient with for example sepsis or severe preeclampsia to monitor the urine output. In this case, the catheter should stay in place until the condition improves.

The urine should be clear, if not, there is a urine tract infection and antibiotics should be administered.

All patients in a critical state (sepsis, severe preeclampsia, eclampsia, bleeding, shock) must have a permanent catheter, and the hourly urine output should be at least 30 millilitres.

If less, the underlying cause should be treated and fluid replacement considered, although not more than one litre over 8 hours for preeclampsia as the risk of fluid overload and pulmonary oedema is increased.

Before applying a permanent catheter, the area around the urethra should be cleaned twice with gauze swabs and normal saline water.

Measurement of the foetal heart rate in childbirth is indicated:

1) On admission,

2) During the 1st stage of delivery:

Every 30 minutes among mothers and babies at low risk, and every 15 minutes if any risk is identified for the mother or foetus, and

3) Immediately after every contraction and at least every five minutes in the 2nd stage of delivery.

The lower limit for a normal foetal heart rate is defined as 110 beats per minute (bpm).

A heart rate below 100 bpm indicates foetal asphyxia and immediate delivery is necessary.

The upper limit for a normal heart rate is 160 bpm.

A heart rate above 180 bpm indicates foetal asphyxia and immediate delivery is necessary.

The foetal heart is best heard by placing the foetoscope over the back of the baby.

Always measure the foetal heart rate for one minute immediately after a contraction (you will need a watch).

Measuring the maternal pulse and the foetal heart rate simultaneously can exclude a mix-up between the two.

Vacuum delivery is a “signal function” of basic emergency obstetric care, and so must be mastered by all skilled birth attendants.

When maternal efforts (pushing) fail or when there is a pathologic foetal heart rate in second stage of labour assisted vaginal delivery is indicated given the head is well engaged.

The major indications for the use of assisted vaginal delivery in the second stage of labour are:

prolonged second stage (over one hour of active pushing), maternal indications (maternal exhaustion), maternal medical illness (cardiac disease, hypertensive disorder) or non-reassuring foetal heart rate.

Prerequisites to instrument delivery are:

Vertex presentation, engagement in the pelvis (1/5), complete dilation of the cervix, rupture of membranes, empty bladder, no suspected true cephalopelvic disproportion, and willingness to stop the procedure if it does not go well.

Different types of vacuum extractors exist.

Most frequently used are the ones with metal or silicon cups and the hand-pump suction devices with a plastic cup.

Both can be used safely, the hand-pump devices have the benefit of the practitioner being in control for creating the vacuum, whilst with the other device an assistant is needed to operate the pump.

Metal and plastic cups are less likely to “pop off” and therefore the risk of failure is only half compared to the soft silicon cups.

Procedure

With the suction off, the center of the cup should be applied 3 cm anterior to the posterior fontanel in the midline along the sagittal suture, the so-called the Flexion point.

The flexion point is an important point in maximizing traction and minimizing detachment of the cup.

As most cups have a diameter of 5 to 7 cm the edge of the cup will be over the posterior fontanel.

No maternal tissue, including the vagina, should be under the cup.

The risk of subgaleal haemorrhage increases if the cup edge is placed on the sagittal suture.

Improper application appears to be common with attempted vacuum assisted delivery and is thought to be a primary factor in unsuccessful attempts.

The vertex is wiped clean of blood and fluid.

The labia are spread, and the cup is gently inserted.

A finger is swept around the cup to make sure no maternal tissue is trapped beneath the cup.

Then vacuum is applied.

For the whole procedure, go through the A-J Mnemonic: Action Card > Vacuum Extraction

Complications

A vacuum assisted delivery is not a procedure without any risks, and should therefore be used when indications and prerequisites exist.

Proper application of vacuum is essential.

Both mother and infant should be examined for birth trauma after its application.

Traction can speed up delivery in emergency situations only when there is cooperation from the patient with pushing.

Proper traction at right angles to the plane of the vacuum cup, and in the axis of traction, is necessary to avoid losing the vacuum.

One type of complication of vacuum delivery is subgaleal hematoma, on rare occasions it may be life threatening.

This occurs when emissary veins are damaged and blood accumulates in the potential space between the galea aponeurotica and the periosteum of the skull.

Signs of subgaleal hematomas include diffuse swelling of the head that may shift dependently when the infant’s head is repositioned.

This swelling indents easily on palpation and may be significant enough to result in hypovolemic shock.

It is treated with a pressure bandage and replacement of volume if needed.

Subgaleal hematoma is quite different than a cephalohematoma, which is a collection of blood that accumulates under the periosteum of a skull bone (usually the parietal) and is characteristically limited to the confines of the cranial bone and therefore the amount of bleeding will not become dangerous.

Intracranial haemorrhage is a rare complication that may be life threatening, the risk is higher in the severe premature baby, therefore vacuum extraction should ideally not be applied before 36 weeks of gestation.

Vacuum delivery also increases the risk of maternal trauma, so the procedure should be performed only on a well established indication and assess carefully any trauma to the birth canal especially the anal sphincter by performing a rectal digital exploration.

Intravenous access is used to administer fluids and drugs.

Equipment for intravenous/intramuscular access should be located in the delivery room.

It should be available at all health facilities for adults as well as children.

It includes:

Antiseptic solution to clean the surrounding skin, syringes, intravenous cannulas, venflons, a stasis hose/band, tapes and cannulas.

Adults:

The grey and green cannulas have a large diameter.

Using them makes the fluid enter the body more rapidly.

Children:

For insertion of an intravenous cannula in the neonate select a suitable vein to place the cannula or a gauge 21 or 23 butterfly needle.

Peripheral vein:

  • Identify an accessible peripheral vein, see illustration.
  • An assistant should keep the position of the limb steady and should act as a tourniquet by obstructing the venous return with his or her fingers lightly closed around the limb. Alternatively use a stasis hose/band.
  • Clean the surrounding skin with an antiseptic solution (such as spirit, iodine, isopropyl alcohol or 7+ % alcohol solution), then introduce the cannula into the vein and insert most of its length. Fix the catheter securely with tape. Apply a splint with the limb in an appropriate position (e.g. elbow extended, wrist slightly flexed).

Scalp Vein:

These are often used in children ages less than 2 years but are most suitable in young infants.

  • Find a suitable scalp vein (usually in the midline of the forehead, the temporal area or above or behind the ear).
  • Shave the area if necessary, and clean the skin with an antiseptic solution. The assistant should occlude the vein proximal to the site of puncture. Fill a syringe and leave the end of the tubing open. Introduce the butterfly needle as described above. Blood flowing back slowly through the tubing indicates that the needle is in the vein.
  • Care should be taken not to cannulate an artery, which is recognised by palpation. If there is a pulsatile spurting of blood, withdraw the needle and apply pressure until the bleeding stops; then look for the vein.

A nasogastric (NG) tube provides access to the stomach and its contents.

NG tubes can also be used for enteral feeding of infants.

It also enables you to drain gastric contents, decompress the stomach, obtain a specimen of the gastric contents, or introduce a passage into the GI tract.

All necessary equipment should be prepared, assembled and available at the table prior to starting the nasogastric tube.

Basic equipment includes:

  • Personal protective equipment
  • NG tube
  • Catheter tip irrigation 60ml syringe
  • Water-soluble lubricant, preferably 2% Xylocaine jelly. Alternatively use water.
  • Adhesive tape
  • Stethoscope
  • pH indicator strips

Insertion of a nasogastric tube:

  • Holding the tip of the tube against the child’s nose, measure the distance from the nose to the ear lobe, then to the xiphisternum (epigastrium). Mark the tube at this point.
  • Hold the child firmly. Lubricate the tip of the catheter with water, and pass it directly into one nostril, pushing it slowly in. It should pass easily down into the stomach without resistance. When the measured distance is reached, fix the tube with tape at the nose.
  • Aspirate a small amount of stomach contents with a syringe to confirm that the tube is in place (if available check that it turns blue lithmus paper pink). If no aspirate is obtained, inject air down the tube and listen over the abdomen with a stethoscope.
  • If there is any doubt about the location of the tube, withdraw it and start again.
  • When the tube is in place, fix a 20 ml syringe (without the plunger) to the end of the tube, and pour food or fluid into the syringe, allowing it to flow by gravity.
  • If oxygen therapy is to be given by nasopharyngeal catheter at the same time, pass both tubes down the same nostril and try to keep the other nostril patent by wiping away crusts and secretions, or pass the feeding tube through the mouth.

CBT content courtesy of Dr. Staffan Bergström.

Indication

Condom tamponade technique is indicated when there is profuse uterine bleeding un-stoppable by AMTSL as an attempt to prevent hysterectomy.

Tools

  • Sterile cloth
  • IV-fluids of any kind
  • Sterile gloves
  • Sterile condom
  • IV fluid set (remove the outermost tip of it so there is a little knob)
  • Ligature
  • Clamp (non traumatic) - minimum 25 cm.
  • Headlight
  • Two (broad) specula - one down, one up

How to do it

Stop the bleeding by external compression of the aorta (See Manual Removal of Placenta video).

Keep the fist in position until the condom tamponade insertion has taken place.

When mounting the condom on the plastic tubing; be careful and maintain sterility.

Tie the ligature carefully several times around the condom below the knob on the plastic tubing.

Tie as tight as possible with reef knot and surgical knotting technique.

The Procedure

Clean the vulva.

Insert the lower most speculum so you can visualize the cervix.

Insert the second speculum anteriorly and place in a similar position.

Unintentional trapping of the vaginal mucosa between the two specula should be avoided, since it is very painful.

Use the long clamp to insert the tubing into the uterus.

Be careful not to grasp the condom but rather grasp the tubing.

Insert until the condom disappears into the uterus.

Fill the condom with fluids.

Start with 500 ml.

It is normal that the condom is leaking a little bit (difficult to tie the condom sufficiently tight to the tubing) – it doesn’t matter.

Continue to fill the condom until the bleeding stops.

If 500 ml is not enough, infuse more.

You can keep the infusion line open to compensate for any loss due to leaking.

Pack the upper vagina with roller gauze to prevent expulsion of the balloon.

Give Oxytocin 20 units in 1 L IV fluids (Normal Saline or Ringer's Lactate) at 60 drops per minute.

A single dose of antibiotics is recommended, for example Ampicillin 2 g IV.

Post-Procedure Care

Monitor vital signs, uterine fundal height and vaginal bleeding.

Monitor urine output every hour.

The condom can be kept inside the uterus for days if transport is needed.

Otherwise, after 6–24 hours, if there is no active vaginal bleeding, deflate the balloon.

If there is no further vaginal bleeding after 30 minutes stop the Oxytocin.

If the woman starts to bleed when the balloon is deflated, insert a new balloon and recommence the Oxytocin infusion; prepare for surgical interventions when her condition becomes stable.

Remove the urinary catheter once the woman is stable.

OR

Header!

  1. One
  2. Two
  3. Three

Airway

Free and safe (no obstruction).

Breathing

Respiratory rate slower than 30 or faster than 60 per minute.

Cyanosis.

Severe chest in-drawings.

Grunting.

Apnoea (no breathing for more than 15 seconds).

Circulation

Signs of shock including:

Pale colour.

Weak pulse.

Heart rate below 80 or above 180.

Capillary refill time more than 3 seconds.

Disability

Poor feeding/inability to suck.

Irritability.

Convulsions.

Decreased muscle tone.

Decreased consciousness.

Vomiting.

Exposure

Temperature below 35.5°C or above 37.5°C.

Red, tender umbilicus.

Severe jaundice.

CALL FOR HELP!

Airway

Position so airway is free. Suction if obstructed.

Breathing

If no breathing, rub the back for 10 seconds.

If still no breathing or respiratory rate slower than 30 per minute: Start bag and mask ventilation.

Bluish colour or difficulty breathing with in drawings or grunting: oxygen by nasal catheter or prongs if available.

Circulation

If signs of shock give normal saline 10- 15 ml/kg IV.

Disability

If the newborn is drowsy, unconscious or convulsing:

  1. Measure blood glucose. If you cannot measure, assume low blood sugar and treat.
  2. If blood glucose is below 2.2 give Glucose 10% 2 ml/kg IV.
  3. Alternatively give expressed breast milk 10 ml/kg by nasogastric tube.
  4. If convulsions last more than 3 minutes or are brief serial seizures, give Phenobarbital 10 mg/kg IM/IV (max 40 mg/kg). Repeat if necessary.

See drug list for further treatment.

Exposure

  • Reheat the newborn, if axillary temperature below 36.5 C
  • Confirm severe jaundice with a bilirubin measurement and treat with phototherapy. If not available: Refer to facility with advanced care.
At any danger sign; suspect severe infection (sepsis or meningitis):

Give antibiotics Ampicillin and Gentamicin IV/IM according to age and weight.

If no improvement after 2 days, change to broader antibiotics, Ceftriaxone.

Respiratory Distress

At labour between 24 and 34 gestational weeks or estimated birth weight below 2 kg give the mother Betamethasone 12 mg IM twice.

OR

Dexamethasone 6 mg four times, 12 hours apart.

Severe Infection

If membranes rupture before gestational week 37 or more than 18 hours before delivery.

OR

If fever is higher than 38˚C before or during delivery.

Give her Ampicillin 1 g IV every 6 hours.

AND

Give the newborn Ampicillin 50 mg/kg IV/IM twice daily and Gentamicin 5 mg/kg IV/IM once daily for at least two days.

If the mother has HIV, hepatitis B, syphilis or tuberculosis follow national guidelines for treatment of the newborn.

Low Blood Sugar

If a newborn has asphyxia or danger signs:

  1. Keep the newborn warm by skin to skin contact with the mother.
  2. Start breastfeeding within half an hour and feed every 2 hours.
  3. If unable to suck give expressed milk 10 ml/kg in a cup or by nasogastric tube.
  4. If not possible or the newborn vomits give Glucose 10% 5 ml/kg/hour IV.

Severe Preeclampsia is one of the following:

  1. Severely elevated blood pressure (160 mmHg or higher systolic OR 110 mmHg or higher diastolic), OR
  2. Persistent severe headache OR
  3. Visual disturbances like flashing lights or blurry vision, OR
  4. Persistent upper abdominal pain, OR
  5. Respiratory distress that could be caused by pulmonary oedema, OR
  6. Decreased urine production (less than 25 ml per hour)

Eclampsia is when a pregnant woman develops generalised seizures.

Usually these women suffer from preeclampsia though 10-20% of women with eclampsia have a normal blood pressure.

Consider as differential diagnosis cerebral malaria or meningitis where fever will be present.

This is a BEmONC Signal Function as stated by the United Nations. However, you still have to act according to government law in your country and should only perform procedures that you have been authorized for.Call for help!
  1. Check Airway and Breathing.
  2. Fits are self-limiting; while convulsing, prevent the woman from trauma and turn her on the left side.
  3. Insert IV lines.
  4. If at a peripheral facility give pre-referral dose: 50% MgSO4 – 5 grams in each buttock deep IM and refer the patient.
  5. At all other facilities, treat the patient the following way: Give magnesium sulphate. As a loading dose you give 4 grams of 50% MgSO4 diluted in 12 ml normal saline or distilled water to make 20% MgSO4 solution and then give slow IV over 20 minutes.
Never give Magnesium Sulphate intravenously fast, as this causes heart arrest!

If no signs of toxicity, proceed directly to giving the first maintenance dose of Magnesium Sulphate; 2 doses of 5 gm deep IM (50% solution) one in each buttock, and after 4 hours in the other (You can add ½ ml. 2% lidocaine for pain relief).

See drug list for more details.

Beware of toxicity

The first sign is loss of tendon reflexes. Also pay attention to urine output, since intoxication is seen in patients with an output < 25-30 ml/hour.A more severe sign is respiratory depression with a respiratory rate of < 12per minute. Then you don’t give the intramuscular dose of Magnesium Sulphate.

At a respiratory rate of < 12 per minute you give the antidote Calcium Gluconate 1g IVover three minutes. At heart arrest give the antidote IV push.

If no signs of severe preeclampsia (see definitions):

Send home.

Schedule follow up appointment in 3-4 days, instruct in danger signs.

Plan delivery at referral facility, induction of labour at gestational age of 38-39 weeks if this procedure is performed and if gestational age is known.

This is a BEmONC Signal Function as stated by the United Nations. However, you still have to act according to government law in your country and should only perform procedures that you have been authorized for.

Admit and observe.

Assess BP every 8 hours.

If high blood pressure persists start oral antihypertensives for example:

Labetatol starting dose: 100 mg orally every 12 hours

OR

Methyldopa starting dose: 250 mg orally every 8 hours.

See drug list for more details.

If blood pressure is reduced to between 140-150 systolic and 90-100 diastolic AND if there are no signs of severe preeclampsia (see definitions), the patient can be sent home.

Schedule follow up appointment in 3-4 days, instruct in danger signs.

Plan for delivery at referral facility, induction of labour at gestational age 38-39 if this procedure is performed and if gestational age is known.

This is a BEmONC Signal Function as stated by the United Nations. However, you still have to act according to government law in your country and should only perform procedures that you have been authorized for.

See definitions.

Admit and treat.

The single most important aim is to keep systolic BP below 160 mmHg!

Insert indwelling urine catheter.

Monitor each ½ hour until stable, then each 8 hours:

  1. Fluid balance
  2. Respiratory rate
  3. Blood pressure
  4. Tendon reflexes
  5. Foetal heart rate

If severe features persist: Plan referral for delivery within 24 hours.

Managing Blood Pressure

At blood pressure between 150-160/100-110 start oral antihypertensives for example:

Labetatol starting dose: 100 mg orally every 12 hours.

OR

Methyldopa starting dose: 250 mg orally every 8 hours.

Persisting blood pressure =/> 160 syst. or =/> 110 diastolic must be treated IV.

See drug list for more details.

Assess blood pressure every 15 minutes.

Repeat after 30 minutes until BP is below 160/110.

See drug list for more details.

Prevention of Eclampsia

If at a peripheral facility give pre-referral dose: 50% MgSO4 – 5 grams in each buttock deep IM and refer the patient.

At all other facilities, treat the patient the following way: Give magnesium sulphate. As a loading dose you give 4 grams of 50% MgSO4 diluted in 12 ml normal saline or distilled water to make 20% MgSO4 solution and then give slow IV over 20 minutes.

If normal tendon reflexes and breathing: Proceed directly to giving maintenance dose Magnesium Sulphate 5 gm 50% solution deep IM in 1 buttock, and after 4 hours in the other (You can add 1 ml. 2% lidocaine for pain relief).

See drug list for more details.

Never give Magnesium Sulphate intravenously fast, as this causes cardiac arrest!

Beware of toxicity!

The first sign is loss of tendon reflexes; a more severe sign is respiratory depression with a respiratory rate < 12 per minute.

Then you don’t give the intramuscular dose of Magnesium Sulphate. Instead you give the antidote Calcium Gluconate 1 gr. IV over three minutes.

At heart arrest you give the antidote IV push.

Sepsis is diagnosed if there is a reasonable suspicion of infection and two of the following findings:

  1. Pulse above 90
  2. Respiratory rate of 20 or higher
  3. Temperature above 38˚ or below 36˚

Septic Shock is diagnosed at the following findings despite adequate fluid resuscitation;

  1. Systolic blood pressure below 90, OR;
  2. Urine output below 30 ml per hour

This is a BEmONC Signal Function as stated by the United Nations. However, you still have to act according to government law in your country and should only perform procedures that you have been authorized for.

Call for help!

Airway

Position so airway is not occluded or at risk of aspiration.

Breathing

If gasping or absent ventilate with bag and mask.

Circulation

Insert 2 wide bore IV cannulas.

Give at least 2 L fluids IV, Normal Saline or Ringer’s lactate in the first hour.

Insert indwelling urine catheter to monitor in- and output

Drugs

Antibiotics intravenous according to local guidelines, for example:

Ampicillin 1 g/6 hrs

AND

Gentamicin 80 mg/12 hrs

AND

Metronidazole 500 mg/8 hrs

If in a malaria risk area,
treat according to local guidelines.

Chloramphenicol should be avoided in pregnant and lactating women.

1. Assess vital signs each hour until stabilised.
  2. Intravenous fluid treatment should be liberal over the next 12 hours to maintain a satisfactory blood pressure of at least 90 mmHg systolic and an average urine output of at least 50 ml per hour.

2. Intravenous fluid treatment should be liberal over the next 12 hours to maintain a satisfactory blood pressure of at least 90 mmHg systolic and an average urine output of at least 50 ml per hour.

3. Access the fluid balance:

a) Record all oral and intravenous input.
b) Record all urinary, faeces and vomiting output.
c) Add to output 1 liter at no fever and 1½ liter at fever because of perspiration.

This is a BEmONC Signal Function as stated by the United Nations. However, you still have to act according to government law in your country and should only perform procedures that you have been authorized for.

Go through the six W’s:

Womb

At chorioamnionitis delivery should ideally be within 12 hours.

At endometritis (puerperal sepsis) evacuation of the uterus (MVA or D&C) if no improvement after 24 hrs.

Weaning

Mastitis or abscess.

Add Dicloxacillin.

Wind

Pneumonia

Treat with Penicillin.

Water

Urinary tract infection

Treat with Ampicillin and Gentamicin.

Wound

Add Dicloxacillin, consider wound revision.

Wings

Treat malaria according to local guidelines if positive test.

Also think of meningitis (neck stiffness), cholecystitis (right upper abdominal pain) and appendicitis (right lower abdominal pain, though could be at level of umbilicus when pregnant). Start treatment and refer to a higher-level facility.

Treat with IV antibiotics for 48 hours after the woman is fever free, then if no improvement oral antibiotics for 5-7 days or more depending on the diagnosis.

Ensure that the HIV status of all women is known, and that appropriate antiretroviral therapy protocols are followed.

Assess the newborn with Apgar score 1, 5 and 10 minutes after birth.

Apgar 7-10: Healthy

Apgar 0-6: Requires medical attention

All newborns need routine care after delivery.

Avoid separating mother from newborn whenever possible and do not leave mother and newborn unattended at any time.

  • At delivery dry and stimulate the newborn. If not crying well or having difficulty breathing proceed to neonatal resuscitation.
  • Assess Apgar Score at 1, 5 and 10 minutes
  • Monitor the newborn closely.
  • Check the cord for bleeding every 15 min, keep it clean and dry. If bleeding, retie it.
  • Give 1 mg Vitamin K (IM).
  • Start breastfeeding within the first hour after birth and let the newborn feed on demand.
  • Examine the newborn, look for danger signs.
  • Apply antibiotic eye drops.
  • Give vaccines according to national guidelines.
  • Weigh the newborn, if less than 2.5 kg consider the newborn low birth weight and at risk of complications such as low blood sugar, respiratory distress and severe infections. Admit and monitor closely for danger signs, consider referral to a facility with advanced care.
  • The lower gestational age or birth weight, the higher the risk that the newborn is unable to suck adequately. Feed by cup or nasogastric tube. See action card for instructions.
  • If clinically stable manage with Kangaroo Motherhood Care: continuous and prolonged skin-to-skin contact with the mother or another caregiver. Initiate at the hospital and continue at home.

At discharge ask the mother to return if the newborn shows any danger signs.

This is a BEmONC Signal Function as stated by the United Nations. However, you still have to act according to government law in your country and should only perform procedures that you have been authorized for. The Golden Minute: By one minute of age all newborns should be able to breathe on their own or should be ventilated with a bag and a mask.

Assess the newborn within the first ½ minute of life.

Resuscitate if the newborn is gasping or not crying or breathing.

Dry and stimulate, if not born in thick meconium.

If solid meconium: clear mouth and nose and suction airways before stimulating.

If not breathing after ½ minute:

CALL FOR HELP!

Clamp and cut the umbilical cord and do the following:

Airway

Position the head in neutral position.

Position mask so it covers mouth and nose, use the “C” and “E” grip.

Give 5 slow inflation breaths each lasting 2-3 seconds.

Observe that chest is moving. If not moving, check the positioning of the head and the mask.

Consider performing jawthrust.

Oxygen supplement is not necessary.

Breathing

If breathing is still insufficient or heart rate is below 100 beats per minute;

Give ventilation breaths at a rate of 40/minute.

Observe chest is moving. If not go back to Airway.

Assess breathing and heart rate every minute.

If breathing is still insufficient or heart rate is below 100 continue ventilation breaths.

Septic Abortion

Septic abortion is diagnosed by the following signs:

Tender uterus

AND

Abnormal, foul smelling vaginal discharge

OR

Rebound tenderness

OR

Any signs of shock (systolic blood pressure below 90) or pre-shock (pulse above 90).

OR

This is a BEmONC Signal Function as stated by the United Nations. However, you still have to act according to government law in your country and should only perform procedures that you have been authorized for.

At signs of septic abortion or at excessive vaginal bleeding:

Evacuation of the uterus must be performed with no delay!Do not delay by awaiting “antibiotic coverage”!
CALL FOR HELP!

Airway

Position so airway is not occluded or at risk of aspiration.

Breathing

If gasping or absent ventilate with bag and mask.

Circulation

Insert 2 wide bore IV cannulas.

Give at least 2L fluids IV, normal saline or Ringer’s lactate fast.

Insert indwelling urine catheter to monitor in- and output.

Drugs

Give antibiotics intravenous according to local guidelines, for example:

Ampicillin 1 g/6 hrs.

AND

Gentamicin 80 mg/12 hrs.

AND

Metronidazole 500 mg/8 hrs.

This must not delay the lifesaving EVACUATION of the uterus.Give antibiotics while you start the procedure.If antibiotics are not available, perform evacuation and give antibiotics afterwards.

Evacuate Uterus

Give appropriate analgesia then evacuate using no-touch technique.

Until 12-14 weeks of gestation Manual Vacuum Aspiration (MVA) is the preferred method.

At a higher gestational age evacuation is by Dilatation and Curettage (D&C) and should be performed in a referral facility.

PERIPHERAL LEVEL

If at a peripheral level without possibility of performing manual vacuum aspiration: Give Antibiotics intra musculary and refer IMMEDIATELY

1. Monitor vital signs and urine output closely until stable.
  2. Treat with IV antibiotics until 48 hours after the woman is fever free, then oral antibiotics for 5-7 days.
  3. Before discharge, advise on family planning and check for sexually transmitted diseases and HIV/AIDS.

This is a BEmONC Signal Function as stated by the United Nations. However, you still have to act according to government law in your country and should only perform procedures that you have been authorized for.
  • Check pulse and blood pressure
  • Large bore IV Access x2
  • X-match Blood
  • Start fluid resuscitation 3 L normal saline or Ringer’s lactate fast!
  • Give drugs:
    As per Government of India's guidelines:
  1. Start with Oxytocin drip. Blend 20 IU of Oxytocin in 1 L normal saline or Ringer's lactate and administer at 40-60 drops/ minute.
  2. If the bleeding continues, Ergometrine 0.2 mg. IV (contraindicated at hypertension and retained placenta).
  3. Misoprostol 800 mcg sublingually if the bleeding continues and Oxytocin is not available.

• Check airway and breathing
  • Ventilate if breathing is insufficient
  • Lie flat
  • Note time of relevant events
  • Reassure woman

This is a BEmONC Signal Function as stated by the United Nations. However, you still have to act according to government law in your country and should only perform procedures that you have been authorized for. Start Here – Call For Help!

While you wait for helpers do the following:

  • Continuous uterus massage
  • Catheterise bladder
  • If strong bleeding persists – apply bimanual compression or aorta compression

When helpers arrive:

  • Co-ordinate:
  • Helper 1 at ‘head’
  • Helpers 2 and 3 at ‘arms’
  • Review other causes - 4 T’s
  1. Tone
  2. Trauma
  3. Tissue
  4. Thrombin

1. Pushing for more than one hour with good contractions.
  2. Foetal heart rate remaining below 100 or above 180 beats per minute.
  3. Maternal exhaustion.
  4. Maternal heart disease or hypertension (though these patients should be giving birth in a referral facility).

1. Cephalic presentation not more than 1/5 palpable above pubic bone.
  2. Position occiput posterior or occiput anterior.
  3. Fully dilated.
  4. Ruptured membranes.
  5. Relevant expertise.
  6. Willingness to stop.

This is a BEmONC Signal Function as stated by the United Nations. However, you still have to act according to government law in your country and should only perform procedures that you have been authorized for. Go through A-J

Ask for help.

Address the patient, tell her what you are about to do while you continue to prepare, tell her that you need her to cooperate and keep pushing when there is a contraction.

Abdominal palpation – the head should not be palpable more than 1/5 above the pubic bone

Bladder empty.

Check that Cervix is fully dilated.

Contractions – there must be contractions to succeed.

Determine position – locate the posterior fontanel (triangular shaped) with your index finger. This is important to place the cup correctly.

Equipment ready – delivery tray, Oxytocin 10 IU for IM injection to the mother, towels, neonatal resuscitator, and vacuum extractor.

Flexion Point – most cups are 3 cm from the center to the edge. Place the edge of the cup at the tip of the posterior triangular fontanel.

Feel for vaginal tissue between the cup and the foetal skull before and after applying suction to avoid trauma to the vagina.

Gentle, steady traction with no rocking during a contraction; with the first contractions downward. During the following contractions, more upward.

Halt in between contractions.

HALT and abandon if three pop-offs, or if three pulls with no progress, or if 20 minutes from application delivery is not achieved.

Intact perineum!

When the head is delivered during the next contraction protect perineum with one hand; squeeze the index and thumb together at the posterior part of the head to prevent stretching of the perineum and lift the head with your third finger upwards and away from the perineum, while the other hand keeps the head from coming too fast. An incision is only rarely needed.

Jaw reachable – release the vacuum and remove the cup.

Do not refer if emergency is not controlled!

Never refer a patient with uncontrolled bleeding, retained placenta, uncontrolled hypertension, unevacuated septic or haemorrhagic abortion or septic shock.

Remove placenta by trained provider.

In cases of prolonged labour:
- If at a peripheral facility, refer the woman to a higher centre with her partograph for further management.

- At a referral facility, amniotomy may be done (also for HIV+ women if on antiretroviral therapy). Reassess in 2 hours and decide on further management if there is insufficient progress.

After emergency management and when in a stable condition, discuss decision of referral with woman and relatives.

Quickly organise transport and possible financial aid.

Inform the referral center.

Accompany the woman.

It is crucial that she is accompanied by a health worker who is trained in delivery care and able to manage an emergency situation, if it recurrs during transport.

Consider to bring a relative who can donate blood.

Bring

Referral note.

Essential emergency drugs:

  • Oxytocin and Ergometrine (alternatively Misoprostol) for treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
  • Oxytocin for IM injection immediately postpartum
  • Hydralazine for IV treatment of elevated blood pressure
  • Magnesium Sulphate for eclampsia
  • Calcium Gluconate for intoxication with Magnesium Sulphate
  • Ampicillin for infections
  • Diazepam for pain relief

Supplies:

  • Delivery set
  • Towels
  • IV-equipment + IV fluids
  • Foetoscope or Doppler
  • Blood pressure monitor
  • Ambu bag
  • Suction bulb

During Transport

Observe vital signs and level of consciousness.

If pregnant check FHR.

In case of excessive vaginal bleeding apply bimanual compression.

If the bleeding does not stop apply aorta compression (can be maintained up to 6 hours).

If the woman’s condition permits:

Keep record of all IV fluids, medications given, time of administration and the woman´s condition.

If in labour during transport:

FHR every half an hour.

If pushing and superficial breathing is not enough to repress this urge, stop the transport and deliver the woman.
